awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Understanding Light-weight Transparent Ceramic Mechanical Response: From Single Grain Boundary to Bulk Material
awd_abstract_narration:
Transparent polycrystalline light-weight ceramics provide a unique combination of processibility, optical properties, and mechanical properties making them suitable for applications as transparent armor, optics for aviation, and high-pressure glass for submarines. Unfortunately, these materials often exhibit greater variations in strength than other glasses, making them less suitable for such high-reliability applications. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is based on the hypothesis that minor changes in chemistry at the boundaries between material crystals have a large effect on the overall mechanical behavior. Understanding what chemistry is favorable at these boundaries could allow for improved engineering of the material and create new markets for applications as a high strength optical element. Achieving this goal will progress experimental mechanics; advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare; and secure the national defense. To establish this hypothesis, mechanical testing and simulation must be performed on samples ranging in size from 1/100th of the width of a human hair (to measure single crystal boundaries) to the size of the entire component.  Newly developed testing methods have only recently made such experiments feasible, thus creating new opportunities to understand this problem. As part of the project, student internships will be provided at the industrial partner, underrepresented undergraduate students will be recruited in the research group, and prospective female students will be motivated through Girls Learning about Materials Camp activity.

The mechanical strength of large-format MgAl2O4 spinel exhibits considerable variability that is hypothesized to result from local variations in grain boundary stoichiometry and chemistry.  However, the granular geometry, grain boundary anisotropy, and variations in grain boundary chemistry make relating simple metrics like average boundary composition and average strength challenging. To develop a mechanism-informed understanding of the mechanical behavior of spinel, this work bridges experimentally relevant length scales: from measuring fracture properties and grain boundary chemistry on single boundaries to predicting the fracture strength of large specimens and their property distributions. The project develops digital particle-tracking methods for mapping evolving strain during single grain boundary fracture experiments performed in situ in a transmission electron microscope. Cohesive zone models developed from associated finite element analyses can be correlated with measured grain boundary chemistries and misorientations. Grain boundary and bulk property distributions as a function of anisotropy can be observed at the mesoscale (dozens of grains). This allows us to define representative volume elements for use in a continuum analysis of the macroscopic samples.  At this scale, experimentally reasonable compositional gradients, residual stress gradients, and grain boundary property distributions will be used to predict the distribution of macroscopic strength.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit outcomes:
We developed and validated the use of Digital Image Correlation (DIC) and Particle Tracking (PT) in a Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM). The novel method can be utilized to map full-field strains in the harsh TEM environment with sub-nanometer displacement resolution. This is the first time that such metrology has been applied to the TEM. This approach will therefore enable more quantitative analyses of microscale mechanical test data for a host of materials, both amorphous and crystalline. Demonstration of our new method was done through the study of electron irradiation induced creep (IIC) in amorphous silica (a-SiO2). We found that IIC in a-SiO2 is well modelled by viscous flow, i.e., a linear dependence of strain rate on stress. We then studied a transparent crystalline material, namely spinel. Initially single crystal spinel fracture was studied using the newly developed full-field measurement method. The next step in the study being bi-crystals containing a single grain boundary. At a larger length scale, we performed mesoscale Digital Gradient Sensing (DGS) experiments on transparent materials with the aim of computing their Representative Volume Element (RVE) sizes, i.e., the smallest amount of material whose response is characteristic of the bulk. Results for amorphous soda lime glass and for crystalline Robax glass were generated. Results for spinel were noisier in part because of lower strain levels and residual stress in the material. Starting from such mesoscale strain field measurements, we developed a novel methodology, based on a stereological approach, for experimentally measuring a stain-based RVE for creep.

Broader Impacts outcomes:
Beyond the broader promise of the TEM/DIC/PT method itself for small scale materials testing, the IIC work performed here provides insights into how amorphous materials deform during irradiation induced creep and highlights dramatic differences between the responses of amorphous and crystalline systems. The results of electron irradiation induced creep in amorphous SiO2 provide new insights into the threshold energies, and their distributions, necessary to induce creep in amorphous materials. This problem is practically important for glassy materials used to isolate nuclear waste, consideration of amorphous materials for structural components in nuclear reactors, and the use of stressed amorphous materials in applications in space. The fracture of spinel and spinel grain boundaries provides insights into the mechanical properties of spinel based transparent armor and how crack-boundary interactions important for dissipating fracture energy occur at the nanoscale.  The project supported the majority of a Ph.D. student’s thesis research as well as an M.S. student’s thesis research, and partially supported a second Ph.D. student.
